content.body:
annevk: given that for 3xx response with no Location header but with a response body, the Fetch spec doesnâ€™t explicitly prohibit UAs from processing the response body, and given that thereâ€™s also nothing in HTML that prohibits it either, I guess that means UAs can choose to do whichever they want with it (process it or not)?

â€¦and lacking any spec requirements around it, itâ€™s not something that can be expected to necessarily behave interoperably?
content.formatted_body:
annevk: given that for 3xx response with no Location header but with a response body, the Fetch spec doesnâ€™t explicitly prohibit UAs from processing the response body, and given that thereâ€™s also nothing in HTML that prohibits it either, I guess that means UAs can choose to do whichever they want with it (process it or not)?

â€¦and lacking any spec requirements around it, itâ€™s not something that can be expected to necessarily behave interoperably?

content.body: sideshowbarker: no, then something would have to be explicitly indicated as implementation-defined
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: no, then something would have to be explicitly indicated as implementation-defined

content.body: sideshowbarker: in this case the response would be returned to the caller as-is, so if you emit a 309 on the server, that's what the caller would see
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: in this case the response would be returned to the caller as-is, so if you emit a 309 on the server, that's what the caller would see

content.body: sideshowbarker: that even holds when there is a Location header, as that's only defined to have meaning for a redirect response, which 309 is not
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: that even holds when there is a Location header, as that's only defined to have meaning for a redirect response, which 309 is not

annevk: I'm not sure that microtask issue has been discussed.  Queuing a microtask without an event loop should be fine, since the one can find an event loop anyhow, but when queuing a microtasks, one needs to ensure there is a task in the loop (currently running task counts).
content.formatted_body: annevk: I'm not sure that microtask issue has been discussed. Queuing a microtask without an event loop should be fine, since the one can find an event loop anyhow, but when queuing a microtasks, one needs to ensure there is a task in the loop (currently running task counts).

content.body: ...which is basically what you say in the initial comment ðŸ™‚
I guess we need a concept of a current task?

smaug: Domenic seems to be saying that it's fine to add a microtask to an arbitrary event loop's microtask queue; I'm not quite able to articulate why that is wrong, but it seems quite wrong as you'd expect microtask order to be consistent within a single task and not have the outside world interfere
content.formatted_body: smaug: Domenic seems to be saying that it's fine to add a microtask to an arbitrary event loop's microtask queue; I'm not quite able to articulate why that is wrong, but it seems quite wrong as you'd expect microtask order to be consistent within a single task and not have the outside world interfere

content.body: smaug: I guess it would violate run-to-completion in some way
content.formatted_body: smaug: I guess it would violate run-to-completion in some way

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> Noam Rosenthal: I also wonder what happens in practice for 103 today. Perhaps browsers match Fetch, but maybe only half of them do or some such.

When we designed early hints we explicitly stated that only `Content-Security-Policy` is read and respected, and only for the purpose of the early hint itself. But I'm pretty sure we don't test that all the rest are not respected. For `Set-Cookie`, I would expect it to be not respected at all or respected only for the early hint fetches themselves, but we never spec'ed the latter
 bashi
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Noam Rosenthal: I also wonder what happens in practice for 103 today. Perhaps browsers match Fetch, but maybe only half of them do or some such.
When we designed early hints we explicitly stated that only Content-Security-Policy is read and respected, and only for the purpose of the early hint itself. But I'm pretty sure we don't test that all the rest are not respected. For Set-Cookie, I would expect it to be not respected at all or respected only for the early hint fetches themselves, but we never spec'ed the latter
bashi

content.body: nothing would run the microtask
at least given how mictotasks should run
smaug: well in the spec the microtask queue is on the event loop so it would run in the next task or as part of some current task
content.formatted_body: smaug: well in the spec the microtask queue is on the event loop so it would run in the next task or as part of some current task

content.body: or does something in the spec somehow trigger the event loop to run
exactly
the next task might never happen
there might not be such
Yeah that's a problem, but it also seems like a problem if it just executes as part of the current task (that might still be scheduling its own microtasks)
annevk: you mean in case of workers?
content.formatted_body: annevk: you mean in case of workers?

content.body: smaug: for instance, or a cross-site document
content.formatted_body: smaug: for instance, or a cross-site document

content.body: scheduling microtasks from outside just doesn't make sense
I mean apparently to some people it does, so we might need more than "just" :-)
well, one can't run microtasks without a task. Isn't that quite clear
so scheduling a microtask which might or might not run, depending on whether there are some other tasks around would be odd
smaug: aah, we have a currently running task on event loop, I can assert that's non-null
content.formatted_body: smaug: aah, we have a currently running task on event loop, I can assert that's non-null

content.body: that sounds good
I wonder if web animations spec has a bug somewhere, if it doesn't guarantee that there is a task
smaug: I think there are quite a few specs that do this wrong, in part because of the promises guide which also did it wrong
content.formatted_body: smaug: I think there are quite a few specs that do this wrong, in part because of the promises guide which also did it wrong

content.body: smaug: they just resolve a promise from "in parallel" or some such and hope things work out
content.formatted_body: smaug: they just resolve a promise from "in parallel" or some such and hope things work out

content.body: ah yes, easy to just resolve a promise at random point
Domenic: ^^
content.formatted_body: Domenic: ^^

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: makes sense. Thanks! I would expect Set-Cookie to work for the early hint preload fetches as those go through the 2xx and above pipeline.
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: makes sense. Thanks! I would expect Set-Cookie to work for the early hint preload fetches as those go through the 2xx and above pipeline.

content.body: annevk: I meant that I *might* expect the cookie from the 103's `Set-Cookie` to be sent to the early-hint fetch requests
content.formatted_body: annevk: I meant that I might expect the cookie from the 103's Set-Cookie to be sent to the early-hint fetch requests

content.body: I wonder if there should be some implicit task created, if there is no task around? Though, I guess that should be created always when resolving a promise in parallel.
... but we didn't spec that
Noam Rosenthal: ooh I see
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: ooh I see

content.body: smaug: I think especially with in parallel you want to create a task as otherwise the microtask can end up in a random task; like if you do setTimeout and do some promise thingies in there, there shouldn't be microtasks in there from things that happened in other event loops
content.formatted_body: smaug: I think especially with in parallel you want to create a task as otherwise the microtask can end up in a random task; like if you do setTimeout and do some promise thingies in there, there shouldn't be microtasks in there from things that happened in other event loops

content.body: smaug: making it easier to resolve promises from in parallel though is something we could work on, although it's not that much work to queue a task
content.formatted_body: smaug: making it easier to resolve promises from in parallel though is something we could work on, although it's not that much work to queue a task

content.body: yeah, perhaps it is better to just require one to queue a task. That forces the spec author and also reader to think what actually happens.
And also to pick a task queue and such.
Domenic: when the navigation algorithm invokes "prepare to run script" the "currently running task" is non-null?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: when the navigation algorithm invokes "prepare to run script" the "currently running task" is non-null?

content.body: I could use some help getting https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1647 reviewed, don't think I'll get to it this week.
I was looking at it at some point, when it was still very unclear what was proposed
beacon or fetch later
hmm, I'm probably not super happy with "trigger when document is destroyed"
or perhaps that doesn't mean all the cases?
Like when OS kills a content process to reduce memory usage
smaug: the idea is to hint to the UA to perform this fetch as late as possible, or after a timeout
content.formatted_body: smaug: the idea is to hint to the UA to perform this fetch as late as possible, or after a timeout

content.body: ... where the timeout is not a DOMTimer (it stays alive regardless of active/visible etc)
it's purposefully left a bit open how this is interpreted in terms of OS integration and situations like "kill due to low memory".

content.formatted_body:
I have a Stack-Overflow-like question. What's a way to rewrite the following whereby "example.unlikely" as input doesn't result in a false-negative? I guess one could hash the input somehow, but that seems really gross?

function parseHost(input) {
  dummy = new URL("http://example.unlikely");
  dummy.host = input;
  if (dummy.host !== "example.unlikely")
    return dummy.host;
  return null;
}

function parseHost(input) {
  const false_host = `${uuid()}.unlikely`;
  dummy = new URL("http://${false_host}");
  dummy.host = input;
  if (dummy.host !== false_host)
    return dummy.host;
  return null;
}

?

m.new_content.formatted_body:
function parseHost(input) {
  const false_host = `${uuid()}.unguessable`;
  dummy = new URL("http://${false_host}");
  dummy.host = input;
  if (dummy.host !== false_host)
    return dummy.host;
  return null;
}

?

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: yeah, I think this is another good reason for adding `URLHost` :-) cc Adam Rice
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: yeah, I think this is another good reason for adding URLHost :-) cc Adam Rice

content.body: I wonder how different fetchLater then is vs pagehide + fetch/beacon.
smaug: it's a replacement for beacon. You can't fetch in pagehide because it would be aborted
content.formatted_body: smaug: it's a replacement for beacon. You can't fetch in pagehide because it would be aborted

content.body: and we need replacement for beacon because?
smaug: https://github.com/w3c/page-visibility/issues/59
content.formatted_body: smaug: https://github.com/w3c/page-visibility/issues/59

content.body: if pagehide has issues on mobile, doesn't this new thing have too
it doesn't! because you're not relying on JS running at a particular very late moment.
instead, you're saying at an earlier moment "please fetch as late as possible", instead of hoping that at that late moment you'll have JS execution
but you just said that OS killing the process in on purpose left a bit vague
so it is still unreliable
The idea is that that timeout is executed on the network process. however, the whole issue of "killing processes" is not entirely specified
(I'm not saying no to the API, just wondering if we're replacing some old unreliable APIs with a new unreliable API)
it leaves reliability to the browser rather than to the web developer. Of course that doesn't *guarantee* reliability if the implementation drops those fetches
content.formatted_body: it leaves reliability to the browser rather than to the web developer. Of course that doesn't guarantee reliability if the implementation drops those fetches

content.body: if the OS kills the whole browser, for example, of course some of these will be dropped
right now the reliability of pagehide is also on the browser, not on the web developer
smaug:  sure.  this came as a shared design discussion between chromium & webkit folks, that making something declarative like this reliable is more feasible than reliably firing `pagehide`
content.formatted_body: smaug: sure. this came as a shared design discussion between chromium & webkit folks, that making something declarative like this reliable is more feasible than reliably firing pagehide

content.body: I know
but it is still replacing one unreliable thing with another reliable thing
which just feels a bit silly ðŸ™‚ even though it might be in practice good, since the new thing might less unreliable
Reliability is on a sliding scale I guess.
If we treated everything as 100% reliable or 100% unreliable we wouldn't get far.
we tried to design an API that gives the browsers a better opportunity at making these fetches reliable
* but it is still replacing one unreliable thing with another unreliable thing

m.new_content.body: but it is still replacing one unreliable thing with another unreliable thing

content.body: I find it a bit odd that when parsing HTML null characters are reported twice as errors. Once during tokenization and then again during tree construction. I'd consider the latter to be redundant. Does anybody have some insight/thoughts?
